title: whether isObject is correct for new Boolean
body:
```javascript
console.log(_.isObject(new Boolean(true))) // true
console.log(typeof new Boolean(0)) // 'object'
```
author: yihan12

comments.body:
And these...
```javascript

console.log(_.isString(new String())) // true
console.log(typeof new String()) // 'object'

console.log(_.isNumber(new Number())) // true
console.log(typeof new Number()) // 'object'


console.log(_.isBoolean(new Boolean())) // true
console.log(typeof new Boolean()) // 'object'

console.log(_.isArray(new Array())) // true
console.log(typeof new Array()) // 'object'

```

@yihan12 Thank you for reaching out.

The `typeof` operator distinguishes only six types: `undefined`, `boolean`, `number`, `string`, `function` and `object`. You will notice that Underscore can distinguish more types than that.

When you do `new Number()`, you create an object-wrapped number. It is a number and an object at the same time. Consider the following series:

```js
_.isNumber(4) // true
_.isObject(4) // false
_.isNumber(new Number(4)) // true
_.isObject(new Number(4)) // true
_.isNumber({}) // false
_.isObject({}) // true
_.isNumber(new Number(4).valueOf()) // true
_.isObject(new Number(4).valueOf()) // false
```

Underscore can also distinguish arrays, dates, buffers, maps and many other creatures. The `typeof` operator would say `object` to all of those.

title: How do you display total number of records in a template?
body: I'm having trouble getting any answers on underscore.js on stackoverflow, so I'm just going to ask here. How do you display the total number of records in a template? In this example, how would I display totalNum?
author: lschneiderman

comments.body:
shouldn't it be 

_.each(items,function(item,key,items) { %>
<%- items.length %> of addresses in this search
<% });

For future reference, if your `items` looks like this:

```js
[{id: 100}, {id: 101}]
```

Then you can render something for each `item` and then display the total number of them at the end like this:

```erb
<% _.each(items, function(item, index, list) { %>
    <!-- print whatever you want about each `item` here -->
<% }); %>
Total number of items: <%= items.length %>
```

If you want to tally during iteration to show something like ‚Äúitem 5 of 10‚Äù, this will work:

```erb
<% _.each(items, function(item, index, list) { %>
    This is item <%= index %> of <%= list.length %>.
<% }); %>
```

@lschneiderman @spattanaik75

title: Logic attempting to reference the global object is overly complicated
author: david-mark

comments.body:
David Mark! Good to hear from you!

People have used Underscore in all kinds of strange places ‚Äî old browsers, Node.js, Narwhal, Adobe Illustrator, with AMD, UMD, various module systems, and so on...

That initial bit of code attempts to safely find the global namespace, whatever the JS environment might be, so that we can restore the previous definition of `_`, in the case that you later call `_.noConflict()` (and also to sniff for old browser globals).

If no global namespace exists, we use an empty one, instead of putting conditionals everywhere the script later mentions `root`. Of course, you could do it either way.

Nothing strange about any of those places. And ISTM that it should just throw an exception if no global object is found (a scenario impossible in a standards-compliant ECMAScript implementation).

Anyway, as mentioned, you need only:

var root = this;

...and I expect you previously had a 'use strict' directive in here, right? That's the only possible way that you could have been led down the path to the current code (not that it would be right in that case either, but similar mistakes are common).

After nine years and who knows how many sets of eyes, it would be nice to get the first line right. ;)

Also, why do you feel the need to "sniff for old browser globals"? As in host objects found only in old browsers? I don't have the stomach to read past the first line of this thing (certainly not in 2019), but that sure sounds like browser sniffing.

I assume this library has come and gone. Found it in a framework and experienced deja vu with that first line. React and other libraries do similar things; as do AMD implementations, UMD, jQuery, etc. Open source developers have a responsibility to set good examples, but few seem to live up to it; always in a hurry to close issues without taking the time to understand them.

Good luck to you! :)

title: _.uniq iteratee function, when run on sorted array, can return extra value sometimes
body:
My understanding is that iteratee in these examples will transform the array to true or false values, get the two unique values, and then return the original values that were the cause of the two unique transformations. 

So in Ex 1 below, the transformed array would be: [false, false, false, true, false, false], so the two unique values would be 1 (false) and 3 (true). For sorted arrays like this, when the 'odd man out' value is separated by at least one other number from the first of the 'commoners', and has some different numbers following it, the result includes the following 'opposite' value as well (in this case, 4).

(tested 10/24/17 in jsbin with "underscore" library added - no version number given)

```

var numbers = [1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4];

var iteratee = function(value) { return value === 3; };
var un = _.uniq(numbers, true, iteratee); // [1, 3, 4]    <-------- Ex 1
var un = _.uniq(numbers, false, iteratee); // [1, 3]

var iteratee = function(value) { return value === 1; };
var un = _.uniq(numbers, true, iteratee); // [1, 2]  <--- is ok
var un = _.uniq(numbers, false, iteratee); // [1, 2]

var iteratee = function(value) { return value === 4; };
var un = _.uniq(numbers, true, iteratee); // [1, 4]  <--- is ok
var un = _.uniq(numbers, false, iteratee); // [1, 4]

```
author: darren-a

comments.body:
if isSorted is true, 'computed' just compare with 'seen'.in Ex1,numbers is not sorted actually.

`computed = iteratee ? iteratee(value, i, array) : value;`

in Ex1 numbers = [1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4] . it is just look like sorted . but the array is [false, false, false,true, false, false] .The array is not sorted.

and  numbers = [1, 2, 2, 4, 4, 3] or numbers = [3, 1, 2, 2, 4, 4]  is sorted

because the array is [false, false, false, false, false, true] or [true, false, false, false, false, false]

Ex1 does use a sorted array, prior to applying any kind of transform. I assume the caller of uniq can only really specify the 'sortedness' of the collection prior to applying a transform.

It seems that, if given a sorted collection, the transform that uniq applies cannot impose its own ordering, ie. 'un-order' the collection, since that could render an inaccurate result.

I'm afraid this is behaving as expected: You passed `isSorted=true`, but the values you were trying to compare were `[false, false, false, true, false, false]` ... which isn't sorted. This will break every time.

title: _.isNumber( NaN ) == true
body: Why `_.isNumber( NaN ) == true` ?
author: judsonbsilva

comments.body:
Hi @judsonbsilva! 

`_.isNumber( NaN )` is `true` because `NaN` is classified as a number just as
`Infinity` and `-Infinity` are.

The `_.isNumber` method is not intended for numeric validation just as `_.isDate` will not validate whether a date object is a valid date, `new Date(Infinity)`.

If you're looking for validation there's `_.isFinite` or
ES6 `Number.isFinite`, `Number.isNaN`, `Number.isInteger`, and `Number.isSafeInteger`.
:) Ohh... nice, thank's
Can this explanation go in the documentation?  We get this question in some form quite frequently.

title: Tests missing from nodejs.org package
body: Hello, I'm working on creating a distro package for underscorejs and we'd like to run the test suite before we install anything. author: orlitzky

comments.body:
Ah, I just noticed `docs` is missing too.

I can always grab these from github, but it's nice to have everything available through the npm registry because then we can script the creation of new packages.

I'm not sure what you mean by "script the creation of new packages", but it seems like your use case would be better served by simply cloning the git repository. npm is doing too much (and giving you too little) for your needs.

I'm creating a distro package for underscore.js. Using git is undesirable, because now every end user needs to have git installed before he can install underscore. That adds between 20 and 100 dependencies to the list, all to fetch a few files. It's easier to just grab the tarball from the github releases page where it's not missing the tests/docs.

I'm only bugging you because the default "get everything from npmjs.org, build it, test it, and install it" code is already written. Having to get underscore from a different place means we can't use the default implementation, but it's not a big deal.
Underscore is far from the only package not including its tests in the npm distribution. It's considered a best practice. You were going to have to deal with this eventually.

title: FEATURE REQUEST: get the max value instead of the max object
body:
Suppose I want to find the maximum age in a certain database of people, where the age is calculated using a function (e.g. a function that subtracts the birth year from the current year). Currently I can get the person with the maximum age, and then I have to ask again for his age, like this:

```
var stooges = [{name: 'moe', birth_year: 1900}, {name: 'larry', birth_year: 1950}, {name: 'curly', birth_year: 1960}];
_.max(stooges, function(stooge){ return stooge.age(); }).age()
=> 114
```

The function "age" is used twice in the code, which is inefficient both for the code writer and for the computer. There can be functions that are much more lengthy and complicated then "age", in which case the inefficiency will be much larger.

I suggest to add a function to get, not the object with the max value, but the max value itself (as  returned from the iterator), like this:

```
    _.maxval(stooges, function(stooge){ return stooge.age(); });
```

In case there is no iterator, the return value will be identical to _.max.
author: erelsgl

comments.body:
Try plucking in this case

``` js
_.chain(stooges)
 .invoke("age")
 .max()
 .value();
```

or

``` js
_.chain(stooges)
 .pluck("birth_year")
 .max()
 .value();
```

Doesn't "invoke"/"pluck" create a temporary array to hold the values of "age"/"birth_year"?

If the stooges array is very large, this might be very wasteful to create another array of the same size, when all I need is a single maximum value...
Then fold instead.

title: uniq should use isEqual for equality?
body:
I was wondering if it would better for `uniq` to use `isEqual` instead of `===` for equality?

``` javascript
a = { id: 1 }
b = { id: 1 }

_.uniq([a,b]) // now we get [a,b]

_.uniq([a,b]) // but could get [a]
```
author: krisleech

comments.body:
Hi @krisleech!
This has been brought up before and I don't think it's going to change.

I've addressed this partially in my own implementation by allowing devs to customize `_.indexOf` which would affect all other strictish checks in methods like `_.uniq`.

I recently changed `_.indexOf` to match `NaN` which aligns with the proposed ES7 `Array#contains` so `_.indexOf([0, NaN, 2], NaN) //=> 1`. This has the side effect of then applying to `_.uniq`, so `_.uniq([NaN, 1, NaN]) //=> [NaN, 1]`.

You can pass an iterator to compare by property currently (`_.uniq([a,b], _.property('id'))`).

Absent a lodash-style rewrite to allow a customized equality function on `_.indexOf`, `_.contains` and all of the related methods that's probably your best bet.
Thanks both for the information

title: _.template code examples. Make <%- more like default/base choice
body:
After using both _.template and handlebars I find very positive that handlebars have escaped interpolation '{{' as default/base one, and non-escaped '{{{' as additional . For some reason I feel like current _.template documentation position '<%=' as default/base one and '<%-' as additional (like "If you really need it") I find it a bit disturbing and this might lead young and not as smart devs use unescaped thing as default.

I don't know how to make it right, but what about rewriting documentation so that <%- will be default/base and <%= as additional?

For example current <%= example is not right at all. Because it compiles HTML! But if I just change this <%= to <%- there won't be example of <%=.

And one more thing. What about changing templateSettings example to match what mustache and handlebars use (where {{ for escaped and {{{ for unescaped) ? In one of legacy projects someone copy-pasted it from documentation and because code base was already there I added escaped one with {{{. Now I have several projects with original handlebar and pseudo one (_.template) with {{ / {{{ have different meaning =)

Btw, it took some time to figure out how to make {{{ regexp. Here is my solution:

``` javascript
templateSettings: {
    interpolate: /\{\{\{([\s\S]+?)\}\}\}/g,
    escape: /{{([^{}]+?)}}(?!})/g
}
```
author: soswow

comments.body:
The current documentation says:

> Template functions can both interpolate variables, using <%= ‚Ä¶ %>, 
> as well as execute arbitrary JavaScript code, with <% ‚Ä¶ %>. If you 
> wish to interpolate a value, and have it be HTML-escaped, use <%- ‚Ä¶ %>

I think that's a fine and accurate description of the available options.

title: _.isEqual on "[object HTMLCanvasElement]" elements with different content
body:
With two canvas of the same size and same properties, but different contents (and different results from "toDataURL()"), _.isEqual returns true.

title: isObject not correctly detected objects and arrays.
author: EvilDevRu

comments.body:
Arrays are objects. `_.isObject` is slightly different from the other `_.isXYZ` methods‚Äîinstead of distinguishing _object instances_ from arrays (`_.isArray`), regular expressions (`_.isFunction`), and dates (`_.isDate`), it distinguishes objects from _primitives_.

`_.isObject(X) == false` only if `X` is a Boolean, number, string, `undefined`, or `null`. It's `true` for everything else, including arrays.
Thank for answer but [] is not {} and introduce confusion in the logic of application.

Something like `_.isHash` would be more appropriate to distinguish {} from [] and other native classes. 
`_.isObject` works fine right now, because `[] instanceof Object` also returns `true`.
Hi @EvilDevRu!  @kitcambridge is correct, arrays are objects too.  Also, there is a great deal more discussion on this topic in old issues if you would like to dig in to it.  :)

title: Self-currying methods
body:
In #1155 my accepted proposal presented the idea of allowing certain methods like `has` and `match` to curry themselves.  That is, if the method received only one of its two arguments it would assume the subject was omitted and return a curried version of itself.

```
var curly = {name: 'Curly', type: 'stooge'};
_.has(curly, 'type') // => true
var isTyped = _.has('type'); // => curried fn
isTyped(curly) // => true
```

Unfortunately, a self-currying method has the extra overhead of having to determine if it was called in a self-currying manner.  Those who don't care to utilize the self-currying feature might frown on this.  As a compromise, we could leave `has` in its vanilla incarnation allowing those who like the self-currying feature to opt in.

```
_.has = _.selfCurrying(_.has)
```

`selfCurrying` would extend the method to layer this feature on top.  There are several methods that could benefit from this: `has`, `match`, `result`, `omit`, and `pick`.  To opt-in for this feature to be made available to all these methods, the developer would simply call `selfCurrying` with no arguments similar to the way `noConflict` might be called.

This illustrates the elegance provided by self-currying methods:

```
_.map(stooges, _.pick('name')) // vs...
_.map(stooges, function(stooge){
  return _.pick(stooger, 'name');
})
```

I like the elegance -- a wow-factor -- even as I do recognize it comes at an expense.  #1163 offers an alternative to self-currying:

```
_.map(stooges, _.partial(_.pick, _, 'name'))
```

Honestly, I don't like having to present the developer with this decision about whether or not to use the feature, but I'm at odds with wanting to preserve performance and still use the elegant self-currying syntax.
author: mlanza

comments.body: I found this very feature just last night in wu.js.  It goes by the name `autoCurry`.

I think that making this decision at the time when you reference the function you'd like to partially apply is a nice way to go (instead of having it be global). Your partial way works, or perhaps an even more specialized function that simply converts Underscore functions into versions which prefill all arguments except the first (data) argument.

```
_.map(stooges, _.forward(_.pick, 'name'))
```

... or whatever. In any case, best explored through a pull request.

title: Use better composition to deprecate _.where and _.findWhere
body:
Both `_.where` and `_.findWhere` are useful; however, it's obvious that the former's counterpart is `_.filter` and the latter's `_.find`.  I think the level of granularity could be improved by extracting the matching algorithm into `_.match`.

`match` would essentially have two possible uses:

```
var moe       = {name: 'Moe', type: 'stooge'},
    curly     = {name: 'Curly', type: 'stooge'},
    larry     = {name: 'Larry', type: 'stooge'},
    abbott    = {name: 'Abbott'},
    costello  = {name: 'Costello'},
    comedians = [moe, curly, larry, abbott, costello];

// 1. direct use
_.match(moe, {type: 'stooge'}) // => true

// 2. indirect use -- use partial application (omitting the object) to get a matching fn
var isStooge = _.match({type: 'stooge'}) // => fn
isStooge(curly) // => true
isStooge(abbott) // => false
```

The benefit of this approach is the reusability with the other parts of underscore.

```
_.filter(comedians, _.match({type: 'stooge'}))
_.find(comedians, _.match({type: 'stooge'}))
_.reject(comedians, _.match({type: 'stooge'}))
_.any(comedians, _.match({type: 'stooge'}))
_.all(comedians, _.match({type: 'stooge'}))

//or keep the matching fn around for a while if that proves useful...
_.filter(comedians, isStooge)
_.find(comedians, isStooge)
_.reject(comedians, isStooge)
_.any(comedians, isStooge)
_.all(comedians, isStooge)
```

The more granular use provides more opportunity for reuse without sacrificing anything.

```
_.where(comedians, {type: 'stooge'}) // becomes...
_.filter(comedians, _.match({type: 'stooge'}))

_.findWhere(comedians, {type: 'stooge'}) // becomes...
_.find(comedians, _.match({type: 'stooge'}))
```

This seems more consistent since the potential in the future is to provide other fns that get the first of something or get all of something.  This approach always relegates getting the first of something to `_.find` and getting all of something to `_.filter`.  

Using this philosophy, there is potential to provide other helper methods that vend functions and provide greater opportunity for composition.  For example, we could do the same kind of thing with the `_.has` method by omitting the object to get a fn.

```
var isTyped = _.has('type')
_.filter(comedians, isTyped)
_.filter(comedians, _.has('type')) // vs. the longhand...
_.filter(comedians, function(comedian){
    return _.has(comedian, 'type')
})
```

In fact, the `has` method itself -- which already accepts keys -- could be extended to accept an object template so that we have a more robust `has` instead of a new `match` method.

```
_.findWhere(comedians, {type: 'stooge'}) // becomes...
_.find(comedians, _.has({type: 'stooge'}))
_.has(curly, {type: 'stooge'}) // => true
```

Would be happy to make a pull request if you accept the proposal.
author: mlanza

comments.body: I like this idea :+1:

@mlanza I dig your composition ideas.

I've done something kind of related to this in Lo-Dash, passing `callback` to `_.createCallback`, in methods that accept a `callback`, to handle shortcuts like `_.find(comedians, { type: 'stooge' })` or `_.filter(comedians, 'type')`, allowing `_.findWhere` to be an alias of `_.find` and `_.where` to be an alias of `_.filter`.

@caseywebdev @jdalton Thanks for the affirmation.  

@jdalton Will spend some time studying Lo-Dash in the near future.  I see you also use stooges in your examples so clearly we think we alike. :)
:+1:  This would be really cool!
@mlanza -- Love it. Feel free to send in the pull request, and get the credit.

It dawned on me that this could work too

```
_.find(comedians, {type: 'stooge'}) //match
_.find(comedians, 'type') //has
_.filter(comedians, {type: 'stooge'})
_.filter(comedians, 'type')
```

by making use of `match` and `has` internally.  The interesting consideration is that every new feature comes with a slight cost to all the old use cases.  I'm not necessarily advocating this. It's hard to know where to draw the line between a robust api and performance.
I think the `has` shortcut looks more like a `pluck`, which is just property access without the `has` check.

title: Please support both fromIndex and isSorted on indexOf
body:
As the title suggests, it'd be nice to see both fromIndex and isSorted as features of underscore's indexOf() function.

This would likely require sortedIndex() to be extended to add a fromIndex variable as a fifth parameter, but the aim to avoid the need to use slice() in order to binary search from a given index.

The change shouldn't harm indexOf()'s current signature, which could remain in use, it would simply be a condition of isSorted that if it is a numeric value, then the next parameter will be used, but if isSorted is a boolean then it will ignore further parameters as normal.

Also, is it possible to support isSorted on lastIndexOf as well? I haven't had a chance to give sortedIndex() a good luck but I believe a binary search can be made to work in reverse.

title: Incompatibility between underscore, modernizr and iOS
body:
On mobile safari, I kept seeing `Can't find variable: slice` messages. Turns out, the Function.prototype.bind polyfill in Modernizr 2.5 was the root of the problem, and removing it fixes the issue.

Just putting this here in case someone else runs into the same problem. Took me a damn long time to trace it to the root.
author: ejholmes

comments.body: Related to #742.
This affects Modernizr 2.5.1 too

Continuing the conversation from #742... I still don't think it's Underscore's business to be hard-testing against your native functions. If you use a broken shim, then that's a problem, but it's not necessarily a problem that Underscore should be masking -- and even if we did, it wouldn't prevent you from running into bugs with your shim down the road.

But I can imagine valid use cases for wanting to override native methods as well. For example, if @jdalton decided that his optimized JS-side replacement for `forEach` was an across-the-board improved version of the native function, he could override `[].forEach` in his application, and Underscore would happily use that version. If the function works, I don't think we should be blacklisting it.

@jashkenas So far devs have only run into problems with Underscore's blind native use. It seems more beneficial to add the check than to be without it.

Most dev's don't replace native implementations nowadays, but they do shim. So as it stands Underscore cannot be used as a low level lib in widgets which may be embedded in other pages and may suffer slowdowns or errors because of its blind use of shimmed code, all issues that Lo-Dash avoids.

title: Need of nested templates - Idea for implementation
body:
I would like to be able to nest templates and searching on Google it seems a common request.

These is my suggestions:
1. Extend _ . template function to ve used as _ . template(templateString, [ _templateName_ ], [context]) 
   -  _templateName_ is optional and it can be distinguished with typeof from _context_ because _templateName_ is a **string** while _context_ is an **object**. So you can also use syntax like _.template(templateString, templateName) or _.template(templateString, context).
   - if _templateName_ is specified the compiled function is saved in an internal array
2.  Use <%t templateName (param1, param2, etc) %> or <%# templateName (param1, param2, etc) %>  to use the previously defined template inside the new template

Let me know what you think and if you want I can implement that.

<%= otherTemplate(data) %>
```

I does not work for me.
The _.template needs to be called twice for the template and the other template and, in my case, _.template is called in 2 different closures.
_.template only ever needs to be called once for _any_ template string. You get back a compiled template function which you can pass around anywhere you like -- including into other template calls.

title: _.create Feature
body:
Would underscore be interested in something along the lines of a utility method that takes an arbitrary number of arguments and returns a new object like Object.create() but cross browser. The general use is the ability to use a merge like .extend() without having to clone the initial object.

Example use case,
```{events: _.create(Parent.prototype.events, {})}

```


What is the typical or recommended approach to this? Are people using Object.create and shimming it? Perhaps using ``_.extend({}, obj, obj2)``?


```
author: iammerrick

comments.body:
Nope -- historically Underscore has tried to stay out of the "how-to-do-OOP-in-JS" fight. See lots of previous tickets...

The recommended approach is to _never_ shim any native. Lots of websites shim `Object.create` in a way that's entirely incompatible with the native implementation. Use prototypes if you're doing it raw ... use a library function that sets the prototype chain for you if you're doing it with a library.

I am not so much making a recommendation for any sort of OOP. I realize people use object.create for that as well but what I am really looking for is a method that merges objects and returns  new one with mutating any source object. Like I said for Backbone child views when the parent uses an events hash, one currently has to clone the parent and merge the new ones; seems a bit silly when you ought to be able to just create a new object from children. I would argue methods like extend and defaults lend just as much to OOP opinion as a create from all these sub children would.

Thanks for the quick response and opinion, you are an excellent maintainer.

Ah, you've already got that -- just as you said. The `Object.create` talk threw me off the scent.

```
_.extend({}, a, b, c, d);
```
Ok that is all I wanted. Thank you sir. :-D.

title: difference() behaviour change between 1.1.7 and 1.3.1
body:
In 1.1.7, difference() seems to identify differences between objects:

```
_.difference({a: "b", c: "d", e: "f"}, {a: "b"})
["d", "f"]
```

In 1.3.1, difference() fails to identify differences.  Perhaps it's comparing reference equality rather than value equality now?

```
_.difference({a: "b", c: "d", e: "f"}, {a: "b"})
["b", "d", "f"]
```
author: duncan-bayne

comments.body:
Thanks for your help sorting this out.  I was relying on the very best sort of undocumented behaviour: behaviour that someone who's worked on the code prior to me has assumed :-)

Are you interested in the above change making it into Underscore?  If so I'll fork underscore, make the change (appropriately tested, of course) & submit a pull request.  

If you'd rather stick with the existing array-only behaviour, I'll just monkey-patch it in our project.
That's a question for @jashkenas and the other underscore collaborators. Personally, I'm indifferent to the change.

I think we should stick with the existing "array-only" semantics. Diffing objects opens up a whole can of worms about shallow equality versus deep equality, and representing changes to nested arrays and objects, and we probably don't want to go there.

title: toArray should convert a single element into an array
body:
One of the patterns i use in Ruby is 

def foo (category)
 Array(category).each{|item| puts item}
end

It would be nice to have something like this with toArray as well. Instead of (in coffeescript)

```
keywords =  if _.isArray(doc.keywords) then doc.keywords else [doc.keywords]
```

Is there a better way of doing this?

If you think it is useful, i can provide a patch for it.
author: sreeix

comments.body:
Sure, just use "flatten"

```
keywords = _.flatten([doc.keywords])
```
Aaarg. Thanks.
I think this solution is too obtuse. I am in favor of adding _.asArray. Rarely do I want to iterate over characters, and that the library lacks a clear obvious way to do so is frustrating.

I dont think we should change _.toArray either. I think _.wrapArray should be in the library. I just had an inferior name for it (_.asArray). I wrote that exact mixin, verbatim. Ill bet lots of people have. It just seems natural to include it in the library. It seems that you would usually want to deal with a string as wrapped in an array, rather than treating it as a list of characters.

@stevo11101: I'd be strongly against including something like that in underscore. No offence to you or @braddunbar, but you should really always know what type of data you are working with. If you don't, you're designing your program wrong, plain and simple. I've _never_ needed something like this because I make sure to either be working with consistently typed data or a data structure like `Either` that explicitly differentiates between the possible types of data.

I would either always expect a list (single-element and empty lists are lists, too, you know!) or write a variable-arity function, which is pretty much the same thing.

In ES5+:

``` js
function foo(/* ...ids */) { return [].map.call(arguments, function(id){ /* ... */ }); }
```

Using underscore:

``` js
function foo() { return _.map(arguments, function(id){ /* ... */ }); }
```
Gotcha.  Thanks @michaelficarra!
+1 for `wrapArray`.  I've always created my own mixin for just same.  It's useful esp. when you consider that the brunt of underscore deals with enumerables.

title: Uniq/unique returns undefined on an empty array in WebKit on OS X
body:
Since, Underscore is influenced by Ruby, I figured that unique-ing an empty array would just return an empty array.

In Ruby 1.8.7:

[].uniq
=> []

Of course the uniq! method does return a nil on an empty array, but it's a destructive method and Underscore doesn't really have those.

Ruby 1.8.7:

[].uniq!
=> nil

Is undefined the correct output when calling uniq on an empty array or should it just return itself or an empty array?
author: eddorre

comments.body:
Nope, it shouldn't return `undefined`...you mentioned that you're using Prototype 1.6.0.1 alongside Underscore; this is why. Older versions of Prototype redefine `Array#reduce()`, which is required for `uniq` to work correctly (see #84 for a more detailed explanation).

Try removing Prototype and then running `_.uniq([])`. The result should be an empty array.
Thanks for figuring that out, **kitgoncharov** -- I might have gone chasing down the rabbit hole after that one.
No problem. Before **eddorre** said that he was using Prototype in his project, this had me scratching my head, too.
Sorry for the false alarm guys. Thanks for looking into this so quickly.

title: uniq/unique doesn't seem to work in Webkit (Chrome/Safari) on OS X
body:
I'm using version 1.1.3 and here is a sample from the console:
a
[1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4]
a[0]
1
a[2]
1
a[0] === a[2]
true
_.uniq(a);
[1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4]

You'll notice that a[0] and a[2] are equal according to the "threequals" operator and according to the documentation, there should only be one "1" after unique-ing the array "a".

Is there something that I'm doing wrong or is this a bug?
author: eddorre

comments.body:
`_.uniq()` returns a new array; it doesn't mutate the original. Try this:

```
var a = [1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4], b = _.uniq(a);
a; // [1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4]
b; // [1, 2, 3, 4]
```

kitgoncharov,

Thanks for the quick reply. It doesn't seem to work for me:

This is output from the WebInspector in Safari:

var a = [1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4], b = _.uniq(a);
undefined
b
[1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4]
a
[1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4]
Hmm...it seems to work as expected for me under Safari 5.0.2. Which version are you using?
5.0.3 - it was released just a little while ago.
Interesting...I'll update my version and see what's wrong.
Sorry, I can't reproduce this under 5.0.3, either. Not sure what the problem is.

kitgoncharov,

Started taking out JavaScript libraries. Seems to be an incompatibility with an older version of Prototype; 1.6.0.1 to be exact.

Aha...that's why. Older versions of Prototype define an `Array#reduce()` method that returns the first element of an array if it contains only one element, or the original array if it contains multiple elements. ECMAScript 5, however, defines a separate `Array#reduce()` function that behaves completely differently from Prototype's version (this version of `reduce` is similar to Ruby's `inject`).

Underscore's `uniq` method uses `reduce` internally, which delegates to the native implementation if available. Unfortunately, it can't distinguish between the native ECMAScript 5 version and the Prototype version, which overrides the former without checking for it.

Prototype 1.6.1 and higher fix this problem; I'd recommend updating to the latest version if you can.

As a side note, however, it's generally considered bad practice to include multiple JavaScript libraries. Prototype's `Enumerable` module provides iteration functions comparable to Underscore's, so I'd suggest using one or the other. Incidentally, this will also avoid conflicts like these, since Prototype augments native prototypes extensively.

title: Extend
body: Why "without extending any of the built-in JavaScript objects" ?
author: trans

comments.body:
Because extending built-ins is often makes your code incompatible with other libraries and scripts. If you want to extend built ins, because you're certain that your JS is going to be run in isolation, I suggest taking a look at Prototype.js, which provides many of the same helpers as Underscore, in a more object-oriented fasion.

But Prototype is also a good example of how extending native objects can bite you -- in previous versions of Prototype, and `Array#reduce` function was added to the native Array object. ECMAScript 5 standardized a version of `Array#reduce`, a couple years later, and browsers implemented it as a native function. Unfortunately, JavaScript's reduce isn't compatible with Prototype's reduce, and any page that loads those versions of Prototype will monkey-patch the native version of the function out of existence...

Sure. I understand the hazards, but it could be an option. If one knows it won't be an issue it sure can be convenient.

Also, there is another way to avoid these issues buy still extend the built-in: using a single access method, e.g. in this case maybe `_` could work.

```
[]._.reduce()
```
Nice. Thanks.

title: conflict with jQuery#map
author: jenmei

comments.body: Oops, I reported this on the wrong account.

Right -- this is one of the whole reasons for preferring Underscore's `map` function to jQuery's -- Underscore uses the same method signature as ECMAScript 5, meaning that we can delegate to the native implementation when it exists. I've heard rumblings about jQuery moving towards the standard ordering, but it hasn't happened yet, and would be a **huge** backwards-incompatible change if they do.

So, if you want to use Underscore to map a jQuery object:

```
_($('.something').toArray()).map(  ...  );
```

Sound reasonable?

The unfortunate thing though is that I would expect underscores implementation of .map. It's kindof surprising to have it revert to jquery's implementation.

The same is true for any other object that implements .map. Maybe you can check to see if the target object is an Array?

I don't mean to belabor this, but I want to expand on this a bit.

When I use underscore, I expect an underscore object with a consistent api, no matter what. At least, that is the expectation when using such a wrapping api (e.g. jQuery).

Using the object's implementation introduces the case where the wrapped object can make unexpected api changes.
I can see the native Javascript 1.6 functions are better because of speed improvements. The difference is that you can guarantee that the interface is the same as underscore's. With any other arbitrary object, you cannot.

Don't worry -- you're not belaboring it at all. This is precisely the sort of discussion that's important to have on the record.

Underscore delegating to the underlying object's implementation of `map` is a design feature, and one that permeates the library. If you think of JavaScript's collection of enumeration functions (`forEach`, `map`, `reduce`, `filter` ...) as being the interface for an enumerable object, much in the same way that Ruby's Enumerable module is, then Underscore allows you to work seamlessly with objects that implement that interface.

In the case of a jQuery object, if we performed an `isArray` check as you suggest, our choices would either be to raise an exception when trying to iterate over jQuery with a for-loop, or to iterate over jQuery like a hash, returning all of the method names and function values, neither of which is what you want.

So, pass what you mean. Either pass a real Array or Object into the Underscore collection functions, or pass a custom object that implements the JavaScript enumerable interface.
